data.title: Ray Charles’ ‘Hallelujah I Love Her So’ by way of guitar hotshot Jerry Reed
data.meta_description: Jerry Reed's faultless artistry knows no bounds in a playful, acoustic guitar-arranged cover of Ray Charles' "Hallelujah I Love Her So," the penultimate track from the Country Music Hall of Famer's 1968 "Nashville Underground" album produced by Chet Atkins for RCA Victor.
data.text:
“When I’m in trouble and I need a friend, I know she’ll stick with me until the end, everybody asks me, how you know, I smile at them and say she told me so.” Seven years into his recording career on Atlantic Records, blind African American pianist Ray Charles composed “Hallelujah I Love Her So,” which soared to No. 5 R&B in May 1956. AllMusic’s Stewart Mason convincingly asserted that the gospel-inflected standard was accented by “one of Charles’ most infectious melodies, a jazzy, almost big band-style large horn section…and Charles sings the lyrics with an almost giddy edge.”

Leap forward to Elvis Presley’s 33rd birthday on Jan. 8, 1968. Jerry Reed was hunkered down with a trio inside Nashville’s hallowed RCA Studio B, tracking “Hallelujah I Love Her So,” the last song slated for second album Nashville Underground. Ten country pop tunes had been in the can since the previous fall, including two destined for Top 15 C&W status authored by Reed — the tongue in cheek Elvis homage “Tupelo Mississippi Flash” and the crooning ballad “Remembering.”
